keyTakeAways: A daring daylight robbery at the Louvre in Paris stole jewellery valued at €88 million, according to a French public prosecutor.
The stolen items include a diamond and emerald necklace given by Napoleon to his wife, a tiara worn by Empress Eugenie, and other pieces from Queen Marie-Amelie.
Four masked thieves used a truck with a mechanical lift and a battery-powered disc cutter to break into the Galerie d'Apollon via a balcony near the Seine.
Investigators found a damaged crown belonging to Empress Eugenie on the thieves' escape route, suggesting it was dropped in haste.
The thieves threatened museum guards, who evacuated, and attempted to set fire to their vehicle, which was stopped by a staff member.
Security flaws were exposed, including one in three rooms lacking CCTV and a failure of the broader alarm system.
The French government and public officials, including President Emmanuel Macron and Justice Minister Gérald Darmanin, condemned the attack as an assault on France's cultural heritage.
Authorities believe the thieves were professionals, and experts fear the items have likely been melted down and sold for scrap or a fraction of their value.
Justice Minister Gérald Darmanin stated that security protocols had failed, damaging France's international reputation.
The French public prosecutor, Laure Beccuau, emphasized that the real loss is not just financial but cultural, and warned that melting the jewels would diminish the value further.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A daring daylight robbery at the Louvre in Paris saw four masked thieves steal high-value historical jewellery, including a necklace from Napoleon I and a tiara worn by Empress Eugenie, valued at €88 million. The thieves, believed to be professionals, used a modified truck and a battery-powered disc cutter to break into the Galerie d'Apollon within minutes of the museum opening. Despite security failures — including missing CCTV in one-third of rooms and a non-responsive alarm system — officials, including President Emmanuel Macron and Justice Minister Gérald Darmanin, condemned the attack as a severe threat to France’s cultural heritage. Experts fear the items were melted down and sold abroad, as they would likely be destroyed to avoid detection. Authorities have only days to recover the items before they are considered lost permanently.
